com.sri.ai.util.math

Class Multinomial

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.sri.ai.util.math.Multinomial
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable

    public class Multinomial
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable
    Multinomials are objects representing a distribution of n objects into m classes, useful in combinatorial problems. This class are such objects but also work as iterators generating all possible distributions of a certain size of a set of objects, and calculating the multinomials number of each of them. The method next() returns the same Multinomial instance on which it is invoked, so you can either use the value returned by next() to get the distribution's properties or simply invoke next() and use the iterator itself to get those properties. For example: 
     Multinomial m = new Multinomial(10,2);
 while (m.hasNext()) {
     m.next();
     int class1Size = m.getClassSize(1);
     (...)
 }
    To avoid modifying the original instance when iterate, use the clone method first.

      • iterate

        public boolean iterate()
        Iterates multinomial distribution from its current state to its successor and returns true, if there is a successor, or leaves it unchanged and returns false otherwise.

        If exhaustively used, this method will generate all possible distributions of a Multinomial object coming after its current distribution, according to the total order defined below.

        A Multinomial created with the constructor Multinomial(int, int) gets assigned the very first distribution in this order, and therefore using this method exhaustively is guaranteed to generate all possible distributions.

        The guarantees above should suffice for most users. We now detail the order mentioned above for those interested in it.

        The order is defined by the definition of the first distribution, and of the successor function. The first distribution of a multinomial of n objects over m classes assigns all objects to the m-th class. The success is defined as follows:

        A single-classed distribution has no successor (the only possible single classed distribution is that which contains all n objects in the single class).

        For a multi-class distribution n_0,...,n_m, the successor is n_0, successor(n_1,...,n_m) if the m - 1-classed distribution n_1,...,n_m has a successor, or n_0 + 1, first distribution of Multinomial(n - (n_0 + 1), m - 1) if n_0 is not n. Otherwise, it has no successor.

        Returns:
        whether the multinomial had a success to iterate to; if not, the object is unchanged.

      • choose
